4.2. Reconstruction of the Anisotropic Pair Distribution Function (PDF)
In any dense system, the positional and BO orders are coupled with each other, so for a complete
description of the structure, one has to consider both of them. The most natural way for such a
description is provided by the pair distribution function (PDF) [
is an average density of particles,
is a volume of the system, angular brackets
enumerate all particles in the system, and
deÔ¨Ånes the probability of Ô¨Ånding a particle at the separation
other arbitrarily chosen particle. Usually for isotropic systems, e.g., simple liquids, due to ensemble
averaging in Equation (19) the angular dependence of
washes out, so one considers the so-called
averaged over all possible directions of the
. However, in the case of a systemexhibiting the BOorder, such angular averaging will lead to
the loss of structural information. Thus, belowwe will consider non-averaged angular-dependent PDF.
is invariant with respect to some symmetry transformations, the corresponding
will also exhibit the same symmetry, as it directly follows from the following
